effective_dosage: Similar macronutrient distribution (45-65% carbohydrates, 15-20% protein, 25-30% lipids) but higher in fibers, unsaturated fats, calcium, magnesium, potassium, and lower in saturated fat compared to the standard diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of the DASH diet on cognitive performance and brain health as part of broader lifestyle interventions.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that the DASH diet, along with other dietary and exercise interventions, shows promise in influencing cognitive performance and brain structure, though the mechanisms remain unclear and require further study.
population_specificity: Not specified (general aging and neurodegenerative disease populations implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adherence to the DASH diet could improve lipid profile, oxidative stress balance, and liver function in obese adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The DASH diet showed significant improvements in obesity markers, atherogenic indices, and liver steatosis biomarkers compared to a low-calorie diet, but no difference in oxidative stress levels. Greater reductions in blood pressure, serum lipids, and liver function markers were observed in the DASH group.
population_specificity: Obese adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) (n=62, with 40 completing the trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between high adherence to the DASH diet and the incidence of metabolically unhealthy phenotypes in adults across different BMI categories.
results_summary: High adherence to the DASH diet was associated with a lower risk of metabolically unhealthy phenotypes, including a 41% reduced risk for metabolically unhealthy normal weight and a 34% reduced risk for metabolically unhealthy overweight/obesity. Similar protective effects were observed for the Mediterranean and MIND diets.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolically healthy normal weight (MHNW) or metabolically healthy overweight/obesity (MHOW/MHO) at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of the MIND diet (a hybrid of the Mediterranean and DASH diets) with the risk of dementia in middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with a lower risk of incident dementia, with a pooled hazard ratio of 0.83 for every 3-point increment in diet score. The association was consistent across subgroups and supported by a meta-analysis of 11 cohort studies.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults (mean age 62.2–66.5 years) from three prospective cohort studies (Whitehall II, Health and Retirement Study, and Framingham Heart Study Offspring cohort).
effective_dosage: MIND diet score (0–15 scale), with higher scores indicating better adherence (mean baseline scores ranged from 7.1 to 8.3).
study_duration: Follow-up periods varied by cohort, with data analyzed over 166,516 person-years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between adherence to the DASH diet and cardiovascular risk factors in a population of Iranian adults.
results_summary: The study found that higher adherence to the DASH diet was associated with lower systolic blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, triglycerides, and cholesterol levels, with the highest quintile of DASH score showing a negative association with hyperglycemia.
population_specificity: 2,831 adults from 27 counties in Khuzestan province, Iran, selected via multistage cluster sampling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify protein biomarkers of the DASH diet using data from randomized feeding studies and validate them in an observational study.
results_summary: The study identified 71 proteins differing between the DASH and control diets, with 19 validated in the ARIC study. These proteins improved prediction of DASH diet adherence and suggested potential pathways impacted by the diet.
population_specificity: Participants from the DASH trial (N=215), DASH-Sodium trial (N=396), and ARIC study (N=10,490).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of the DASH diet on the prevention and treatment of metabolic syndrome (MetS) and discuss its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that the DASH diet, along with the Mediterranean diet, has positive effects on metabolic syndrome, including improvements in risk factors like blood pressure and dyslipidaemia. It recommends increasing fiber-rich, low-glycaemic-index foods, fish, dairy, nuts, and replacing saturated fats with unsaturated fats.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of metabolic syndrome (general population not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between the MIND diet (a hybrid of the Mediterranean and DASH diets) and cognitive resilience, measured by higher cognitive levels and slower cognitive decline relative to neuropathology.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with better cognitive resilience, including higher cognitive levels (mean difference = 0.34) and slower cognitive decline (mean difference = 0.27) compared to the lowest tertile of MIND diet adherence, after adjusting for neuropathology. The overall MIND diet score showed a stronger association with cognitive resilience than its individual food components.
population_specificity: 578 deceased older adults with longitudinal cognitive data and post-mortem neuropathology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether pre-treatment diet quality indices, including the DASH diet, were associated with changes in self-reported cognition during chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that total DASH diet scores did not predict changes in cognitive function or cognitive abilities during chemotherapy. However, a higher ratio of monounsaturated to saturated fat intake (a component of some diet indices) was associated with less cognitive decline.
population_specificity: 96 participants (mean age 59 ± 10.8 years, 69% female) undergoing chemotherapy for cancer.
study_duration: Cognitive assessments were conducted before the first infusion and 5 days later.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the role of western diet-induced oxidative stress and inflammation in hypertension pathogenesis and evaluate the effectiveness of various diets, including the DASH diet, in its prevention.
results_summary: The study found that the DASH diet is effective in preventing hypertension by improving vascular function, alongside other diets like Indo-Mediterranean and Japanese diets, which also show potential in reducing blood pressure through specific functional foods and nutrients.
population_specificity: General population with a focus on hypertension risk factors (e.g., high salt/sugar intake, sedentary behavior, obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential beneficial effects of the DASH diet on the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that the DASH diet, along with the Mediterranean and MIND diets, may have a beneficial effect on reducing the risk of Alzheimer's disease, though the data are described as scarce and controversial.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, particularly those at risk for Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of a MIND diet and forest bathing (FB) versus the MIND diet alone on hypertension and related health outcomes in older Chinese patients.
results_summary: The study found that both the MIND diet alone and combined with FB led to reductions in systolic blood pressure (though not statistically significant between groups), improved lipid profiles (lower total cholesterol and LDL-C), and reduced triglycerides and glucose levels. The MIND-FB group also showed significant reductions in anxiety and negative mood states.
population_specificity: Older Chinese patients (aged >50) with stages 1 or 2 hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of the DASH diet on 10-year ASCVD risk compared to a control diet and a fruits and vegetables (F/V) diet.
results_summary: The DASH and F/V diets reduced 10-year ASCVD risk by approximately 10% compared to the control diet, with more pronounced effects in women and Black adults. The DASH diet showed a greater relative reduction in ASCVD risk due to systolic blood pressure effects, but this was partially offset by its impact on high-density lipoprotein levels.
population_specificity: 459 adults aged 22-75 years without CVD and not taking antihypertensive or diabetes medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of the DASH diet in reducing the risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) and improving outcomes for patients with or at risk of CRC.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to the DASH diet was associated with a reduced risk of CRC, prolonged patient survival, and delayed disease progression. The diet was highlighted as beneficial alongside other dietary patterns like the Mediterranean diet and ketogenic diet.
population_specificity: Individuals at high risk of CRC or those diagnosed with CRC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of the DASH diet, with and without physical activity guidance, on blood pressure, glycemic control, lipid profile, weight, and body composition in older patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and hypertension.
results_summary: Both groups (DASH diet alone and DASH diet with physical activity) showed significant reductions in weight, BMI, and waking diastolic blood pressure, but no differences were found between the groups in changes to weight, BMI, body composition, glycemic control, lipid profile, or insulin sensitivity. The DASHPED group increased physical activity by 1721 steps/day, but this did not lead to additional benefits over diet alone.
population_specificity: Patients aged 60 years or older with T2DM and uncontrolled hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess adherence to dietary guidelines, derive diet quality scores (including DASH), and evaluate the inflammatory potential of diets in people with cystic fibrosis (PWCF).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the DASH diet's effects, as the study is described as ongoing or not yet completed.
population_specificity: Adults with cystic fibrosis (PWCF)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between the MIND diet (a hybrid of the Mediterranean and DASH diets) and the incidence of open-angle glaucoma (iOAG), as well as compare its effects to the Mediterranean diet and Dutch dietary guidelines.
results_summary: Greater adherence to the MIND diet was associated with a decreased risk of iOAG, particularly due to higher intake of green leafy vegetables, berries, and fish. No significant associations were found between the Mediterranean diet or Dutch dietary guidelines and iOAG, nor were any of the diets linked to intraocular pressure (IOP).
population_specificity: Participants in the Rotterdam Study, Netherlands, with 170 cases of iOAG and matched healthy controls.
effective_dosage: Not specified (adherence measured via food frequency questionnaire).

study_goal: To determine the association of the DASH diet with cognitive decline in older adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D).
results_summary: The study found that while high adherence to the MIND and MEDI diets was associated with slower cognitive decline, the DASH diet did not show significant independent associations with cognitive outcomes in the multivariable model.
population_specificity: Older adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (N = 960).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of the DASH diet in managing cardiovascular disease (CVD) by modulating classical and emerging risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that the DASH diet is effective in modulating CVD risk factors, including hypertension, dyslipidaemia, and emerging factors like inflammatory status and oxidative stress, supported by evidence from epidemiological studies, RCTs, and meta-analyses.
population_specificity: General population with cardiovascular risk factors (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet (a hybrid of the Mediterranean and DASH diets) and prevention of age-associated decline in muscle strength, measured by hand grip strength (HGS), in the Kurdish population in Iran.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet and high-protein diet was associated with lower odds of poor HGS, while adherence to an unhealthy diet increased the odds of poor HGS. The MIND diet showed a 35% lower odds ratio of poor HGS compared to the lowest adherence category.
population_specificity: 3181 Kurdish adults (48.5% men) aged 35-65 years from the Ravansar non-communicable diseases (RaNCD) cohort study in Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adherence to the MIND diet (a hybrid of Mediterranean and DASH diets) could modify the association of genetic risk for Alzheimer’s Dementia (AD) with incident dementia and cognitive decline.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet and lower genetic risk scores were associated with a lower risk of dementia in two cohorts (MAP and WHIMS) and slower cognitive decline in one cohort (MAP), but no associations were found in the third cohort (CHAP). No gene-diet interactions were consistently replicated across cohorts.
population_specificity: Older US men and women from three cohorts: Chicago Health and Aging Project (CHAP, n = 2449), Rush Memory and Aging Project (MAP, n = 725), and Women’s Health Initiative Memory Study (WHIMS, n = 5308).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between adherence to the DASH diet and cognitive performance, as well as potential cardio-metabolic mechanisms in middle-aged adults.
results_summary: Adherence to the DASH diet was significantly associated with lower augmentation index and reduced cholesterol, but not with metabolic syndrome severity or arterial stiffness. No significant relationship was found between the DASH diet and cognitive performance.
population_specificity: 141 middle-aged adults (mean age 52.84 years, SD = 6.87 years) with varying diet quality.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of modest salt reduction combined with the Chinese Modified DASH (CM-DASH) diet on sodium and potassium intake, mean arterial pressure, and pulse pressure in hypertensive patients with type II diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that modest salt reduction combined with the CM-DASH diet significantly reduced sodium intake and mean arterial pressure, and increased potassium intake, though the difference between intervention and control groups was not statistically significant. The effects on pulse pressure were also significant in both groups.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients with type II diabetes (59 participants, 25 men).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention group used 52% low-sodium salt and DASH diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the DASH diet modifies the association between genetic predisposition to smoking and cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality.
results_summary: The study found that the DASH diet significantly modified the association between genetic predisposition to smoking and CVD mortality, with higher CVD mortality observed among individuals with lower DASH scores.
population_specificity: 23,760 Chinese adults from the Singapore Chinese Health Study, free of cancer and CVD at recruitment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether diet quality, specifically the DASH diet, could modify the association between comorbidity and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that higher DASH diet quality was associated with improved HRQoL in stroke patients, particularly those with comorbidities, suggesting that diet quality can mitigate the adverse effects of comorbidity on HRQoL.
population_specificity: 951 stroke patients in Vietnam, with 53.7% aged ≥65 years and 49.9% having comorbidities.
study_duration: Cross-sectional study conducted from December 2019 to December 2020 (no specific intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a legume-enriched DASH diet on blood pressure and urinary sodium/potassium in participants with type 2 diabetes, and whether changes in specific food groups influenced blood pressure.
results_summary: Both the traditional and legume-based DASH diets reduced systolic blood pressure (SBP) and urinary sodium, with greater reductions in the legume-based group. Legume intake above 95.8 g/day significantly decreased SBP, and refined grains, fruits, sweets, energy, sodium, and vegetables showed varying relationships with SBP.
population_specificity: Participants with type 2 diabetes (n=300, split into two intervention groups).
effective_dosage: Legume intake of more than 95.8 g/day in the legume-based DASH diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sodium reduction based on a modified DASH diet on blood pressure in hypertensive patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both the low sodium and common salt groups showed significant reductions in blood pressure, with a more pronounced decrease in the low sodium group, though the difference between groups was not statistically significant. Sodium intake decreased and potassium intake increased in the low sodium group, while the common salt group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of including legumes in a hypocaloric DASH diet on fasting plasma glucose and cardiometabolic risk factors in overweight and obese patients with type 2 diabetes, and to assess the modulatory effects of the TCF7L2 rs7903146 gene variant.
results_summary: Both hypocaloric DASH diets reduced FPG, insulin resistance, and lipid profiles, but the legume-based DASH diet showed greater improvements in FPG and HOMA-IR. No interaction was found between the TCF7L2 rs7903146 variant and the dietary interventions on glycemic parameters.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese patients with type 2 diabetes, aged 30-65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association of potassium intake in low sodium high potassium (LSHP) diets with nutritional content and diet cost compared to a usual Indonesian diet.
results_summary: The LSHP diet had significantly higher carbohydrate, protein, fibre, magnesium, calcium, vitamin C, potassium density, and diet cost but lower total fat, saturated fat, and energy density than the usual diet. A strong positive correlation was found between fibre, potassium, and diet cost.
population_specificity: Not specified beyond typical Indonesian diet consumers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and synthesize current empirical research on the cognitive benefits of the DASH diet and provide considerations for healthcare providers.
results_summary: The DASH diet showed evidence of cognitive benefits and had stronger operationalization compared to other diets, though more longitudinal studies and randomized clinical trials are recommended.
population_specificity: Adults seeking to optimize cognition via dietary improvements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a calorie-restricted DASH diet on myostatin and follistatin levels, body composition, and cardiometabolic biomarkers in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that a calorie-restricted DASH diet reduced myostatin levels and the myostatin-to-follistatin ratio, with correlations to improved body composition and cardiometabolic health, but no change in follistatin levels.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65 years and older (17 females, 11 males).
effective_dosage: 85 g or 170 g of fresh lean beef daily within a standardized DASH diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between adherence to the MIND diet (a variant of the DASH diet) and the odds of developing multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Adherence to the MIND diet was associated with reduced odds of MS, particularly with higher consumption of green leafy vegetables, other vegetables, and beans, while higher intake of cheese, poultry, pastries, sweets, and fried/fast foods increased MS odds.
population_specificity: 77 patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and 148 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the evidence on the blood pressure-lowering effects of salt restriction within the DASH diet and Mediterranean diet, and compare their standalone and combined effects.
results_summary: The DASH diet significantly lowers blood pressure, especially in hypertensive individuals, with a greater effect when combined with salt reduction (-8.9/-4.5 mmHg) than either intervention alone. Salt reduction in the DASH diet produces less than half the BP-lowering effect compared to salt reduction without the DASH diet.
population_specificity: Adults with prehypertension or hypertension.
effective_dosage: Salt reduction by 2.3 g per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of the DASH diet on clinical, quality of life, and mental health outcomes in women with migraine.
results_summary: The DASH diet significantly reduced migraine frequency and severity, and improved depression and stress scores compared to the control group, though quality of life and anxiety outcomes were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Women aged 20-50 years with migraine.
effective_dosage: The DASH diet provided 15-20% of total daily energy from proteins, 25-30% from fats, and 55-60% from carbohydrates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of the DASH diet on cellular immunity, anthropometric, biochemical, and body composition parameters in individuals with overweight and obesity, potentially presenting metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The DASH diet led to significant reductions in waist circumference, fat percentage, visceral adipose tissue, weight, and lymphocyte subpopulations, but no significant changes in biochemical parameters. A relationship between immune cell changes and metabolic improvements was observed.
population_specificity: Young adults with overweight and obesity, potentially with metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between the MIND diet (which includes DASH principles) and the risk of all-cause mortality, CVD mortality, and nonfatal CVD events over a long-term follow-up period.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet (incorporating DASH elements) was associated with lower risks of all-cause mortality (HR 0.93) and CVD mortality (HR 0.90), but no significant association was found with nonfatal CVD events.
population_specificity: 10,009 Australian adults (mean age 51.8 years; 52% female).
study_duration: Mean follow-ups of 17.7 years (all-cause mortality), 17.4 years (CVD mortality), and 9.6 years (nonfatal CVD events).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of the modified DASH diet on blood pressure and cardiovascular risk factors in hypertensive and pre-hypertensive adults.
results_summary: The modified DASH diet significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, waist circumference, and triglyceride concentration, with greater reductions observed in patients with higher baseline BP or BMI and longer follow-up periods.
population_specificity: Hypertensive and pre-hypertensive adults
study_duration: Varied (follow-up periods >8 weeks showed more marked effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate associations between the MIND diet (a hybrid of Mediterranean and DASH diets) and physical function, grip strength, and functional impairment in older adults.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with lower odds of physical function impairment, slower functional decline, and greater grip strength in older adults over a median 6-year follow-up.
population_specificity: Men and women (mean age 68 ± 14 years) from the Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging (n = 1358).
effective_dosage: Not specified (diet assessed by FFQ, scored based on 15 food groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the evidence for the available dietary approaches, including the DASH diet, for patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that the DASH diet can be used in patients with NAFLD, but it does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes compared to other dietary patterns like the Mediterranean diet.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current evidence on DASH diet interventions for heart failure (HF) management and develop initial recommendations for its outpatient implementation.
results_summary: The abstract suggests DASH diet interventions may positively impact HF patients but highlights limitations such as small sample sizes and lack of randomization, calling for more rigorous studies to establish definitive evidence.
population_specificity: Heart failure (HF) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of the DASH diet in the prevalence and progression of metabolic syndrome (MetS) across children, adolescents, and adults.
results_summary: Greater adherence to the DASH diet was associated with a reduced risk of MetS in observational studies, though interventional studies showed mixed results regarding changes in metabolic characteristics.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between the DASH and Mediterranean dietary patterns and metabolic syndrome (MetS) in Iranian adults.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the DASH diet was associated with reduced odds of MetS and abdominal obesity in women, with a significant decreasing trend across quintiles. The Mediterranean diet showed no significant relationship with MetS but reduced fasting blood glucose levels and abdominal obesity in women.
population_specificity: Iranian adults (2,221 participants, including women and men) from the Yazd Health Study (YaHS) and Yazd Nutrition Study (TAMYZ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between the MIND diet (which includes the DASH diet) and cognitive functioning in older adults, comparing its efficacy to other plant-rich diets.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to the MIND diet was positively associated with specific cognitive domains and global cognitive function in older adults, outperforming other plant-rich diets, including the DASH diet. However, the DASH diet itself was not the primary focus, and its standalone efficacy was not detailed.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of glycemic index (GI) and carbohydrate amount on qualitative aspects of diet acceptability, including hunger, satisfaction, and gastrointestinal symptoms, in DASH-style diets.
results_summary: Higher carbohydrate DASH-style diets increased diet satisfaction but also increased hunger and heartburn, while higher GI diets decreased satisfaction without affecting hunger or heartburn. All intervention diets reduced heartburn but increased diarrhea/loose stools and bloating compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (BMI ≥25 kg/m²) with a mean age of 52 years, 52% women, and 51% non-Hispanic black.
effective_dosage: Four DASH-style diets varying in carbohydrate amount (40% vs. 58% kcal) and GI (≥65 vs. ≤45).
study_duration: Each diet was consumed for 5-week periods, separated by 2-week washouts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether changes in diet quality (DASH diet) are associated with changes in inflammatory markers relevant to asthma pathophysiology.
results_summary: The study found that improved DASH diet quality was inversely associated with serum concentrations of proinflammatory markers and asthma-related proteins, suggesting potential benefits for reducing inflammation in poorly controlled asthma. Decreases in specific serum proteins were also correlated with improved asthma control over the 6-month study period.
population_specificity: Adult patients with poorly controlled asthma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association of diet quality, measured by the DASH pattern score, with metabolic syndrome (MetS) and its components in African-American adolescents and youth.
results_summary: Higher DASH pattern scores were associated with lower odds of hypertensive blood pressure, and higher AHEI-2010 scores were linked to lower odds of MetS. Diet quality in the studied population was generally low.
population_specificity: African-American adolescents and youth aged 12-21 years from NHANES (2005-2016 cycles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a calorie-restricted DASH-like diet on cardiometabolic health indicators in sedentary obese older adults, comparing different lean beef intake amounts.
results_summary: The study found that the DASH-like diet improved multiple cardiometabolic biomarkers (e.g., reduced cholesterol, LDL-C, glucose, and inflammatory markers) regardless of beef intake amount, with correlations between body composition changes and biomarker improvements.
population_specificity: Sedentary, obese older adults (mean age 70.8 years, BMI 32 ± 6.9 kg/m²) from a rural community, including both females (n = 17) and males (n = 11).
effective_dosage: 3 oz (85 g) or 6 oz (170.1 g) of lean fresh beef daily within a standardized calorie-restricted DASH-like diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the associations of dietary bioactive compounds, including the DASH diet, with biomarkers of adiposity, antioxidant status, oxidative stress, and inflammation in women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: The study found that the DASH diet increased antioxidant enzyme levels in women with GDM, suggesting potential benefits for improving antioxidant status and inflammation biomarkers. However, the abstract does not provide detailed efficacy data or statistical significance for these outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize preclinical and clinical evidence on the DASH diet's potential neuroprotective effects and its role in Alzheimer's disease prevention.
results_summary: The study suggests the DASH diet, along with other dietary patterns like MeDi and MIND, may offer brain protection and AD prevention due to its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, though specific efficacy data for DASH alone is not detailed.
population_specificity: Preclinical and clinical populations, including animal models and human studies (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate longitudinal changes in dietary quality indices, including the DASH diet, over 10 years in a Mediterranean population and identify predictors of improvement.
results_summary: The study found modest improvements in DASH diet scores over 10 years, though the changes were smaller compared to other indices like MEDAS and MDS. Baseline predictors of improvement included being female, older, and more physically active.
population_specificity: Spanish university graduates (2,244 men and 3,271 women) with a mean baseline age of 36.3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of dietary fiber, including the DASH diet, on diabetic kidney disease (DKD) by assessing renal outcomes such as albuminuria, proteinuria, and eGFR.
results_summary: The study found that a vegetarian dietary pattern may have beneficial effects on renal outcomes like albuminuria and eGFR, but the individual effect of fiber intake on DKD could not be conclusively evaluated. The DASH diet's specific impact was not separately highlighted in the results.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes (type 1 and type 2), aged 58.3 years on average, 49% female.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a physical activity program (10,000 steps/day) combined with monthly dietary counseling on body composition, biological parameters, resting energy expenditure, and health-related quality of life in obese individuals.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved anthropometric data (e.g., reduced body mass, BMI, fat mass), increased resting energy expenditure, and enhanced physical domains of health-related quality of life and anxiety. No significant changes were observed in biological parameters.
population_specificity: 35 obese adults (26 women; mean age 39.2 ± 13.4 years, mean BMI 38.3 ± 6.6 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Qualitative dietary advice (cookbook with low-calorie recipes and dietary advice) provided monthly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and acceptability of an intensive nutrition intervention for lung cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy and assess its impact on nutritional, fatigue, and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The intervention group showed clinically important improvements in weight, fat-free mass, physical well-being, and functional well-being, along with higher satisfaction with nutritional care, though confidence intervals were wide and often included zero. Recruitment feasibility and intervention acceptability were demonstrated, suggesting potential for larger trials.
population_specificity: Patients with lung cancer undergoing (chemo)radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if radiation therapists (RTs) in Canada could identify nutrition-related side effects in cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy and recognize when referrals to dietitians were needed.
results_summary: Most RTs reported being asked for nutrition advice by patients and demonstrated knowledge in recognizing patients needing nutrition intervention, though they lacked confidence. Educational sessions and referral algorithms were suggested to improve care quality and patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy in Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of early individualized dietary counseling on weight loss, complications, and hospital stay in head and neck cancer patients at risk of undernutrition.
results_summary: Dietary counseling reduced overall postoperative complications (44% vs. 70%) but did not significantly affect weight loss, major complications, or length of hospital stay.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed head and neck cancer patients with (risk of) undernutrition.
study_duration: From diagnosis to end of treatment (duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dietary counseling in improving nutritional status among tuberculosis patients, including those with and without HIV co-infection.
results_summary: The study found that dietary counseling did not effectively recover patients from malnutrition, with persistent high rates of energy and micronutrient deficiencies, particularly among HIV+ patients, despite the intervention. No significant improvement was observed in BMI, TSF, or MUAC measurements over the 180-day period.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing tuberculosis therapy, including both HIV-infected and non-infected individuals, predominantly male, with low income and at least six years of schooling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of motivational interviewing (MI) delivered by primary care providers and registered dietitians on reducing BMI percentile in overweight children aged 2-8.
results_summary: The study found that MI delivered by both providers and registered dietitians (Group 3) resulted in statistically significant reductions in child BMI percentile compared to usual care (Group 1). The adjusted BMI percentile at 2-year follow-up was lowest in Group 3 (87.1), with a mean change from baseline of -4.9, indicating a modest but significant effect.
population_specificity: Parents of overweight children aged 2-8 years.
effective_dosage: Group 2 received 4 MI sessions from providers; Group 3 received 4 provider MI sessions plus 6 RD MI sessions over 2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining individualized swallowing therapy with dietary counseling improved normalcy of food intake (NFI) and dysphagia recovery compared to dietary counseling alone in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found no overall difference in NFI, dysphagia severity, social eating, or nutritional status between the groups. However, the intervention group showed a slight improvement in dysphagia recovery at week 10, though this effect diminished by week 30.
population_specificity: Patients with stage II to IV head and neck cancer treated with postoperative (chemo)radiation.
study_duration: Measurements were taken at the start of treatment and in weeks 6, 10, 18, and 30.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary counseling on the nutritional status of children with food allergy (FA).
results_summary: Dietary counseling significantly improved energy intake, anthropometric measures, and laboratory biomarkers of nutritional status in children with FA, bringing their energy intake to levels similar to control children without FA.
population_specificity: Children aged 6 to 36 months with food allergy (FA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether infancy-onset dietary counseling targeting reduced saturated fat intake could lower the risk of metabolic syndrome (MetS) in adolescence.
results_summary: The study found that repeated dietary counseling significantly reduced the relative risk of MetS (RR 0.59) and specifically decreased risks of high blood pressure and high triglycerides, with a nonsignificant trend toward reduced waist circumference.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 15-20 years, part of the STRIP longitudinal prevention trial.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary counseling frequency/details not provided).
study_duration: From infancy to early adulthood (approximately 20 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of individual dietary counseling on nutritional status among community-dwelling older people aged 75 years or older at risk of malnutrition.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in Mini Nutritional Assessment (MNA) scores and serum albumin levels in the intervention group compared to the control group, suggesting dietary counseling improved nutritional status.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling people aged 75 years or older at risk of malnutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of individualized dietary counseling based on narrative interview techniques for maintaining body weight reduction and promoting healthier dietary behaviors in obese subjects.
results_summary: The study found that individualized dietary counseling led to significant body weight reductions (10.9% at 12 weeks and 9.7% at 52 weeks) and was associated with sustained dietary habit changes, particularly in cooking methods and increased vegetable oil consumption. However, no significant difference in weight maintenance was observed between the 12th and 52nd weeks.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (100 out of 400 screened patients met inclusion criteria).
effective_dosage: 45-minute educational program with motivation counseling at 0, 6, and 12 weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks of active intervention with follow-up to 52 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal dietary counseling to increase unsaturated fatty acid intake affects infant fatty acid status.
results_summary: Dietary counseling led to higher maternal intake of polyunsaturated fatty acids and lower intake of saturated fatty acids, which was reflected in cord blood triacylglycerols (lower n-6 to n-3 ratio and higher n-3 fatty acids). However, no changes were observed in cord blood cholesteryl esters or infant fatty acid fractions at 1 month, possibly due to modest dietary changes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (from the first trimester) and their infants.
study_duration: From the first trimester of pregnancy until delivery.
